qas.question: What needs to be known to calculate torque?
How are the many calculations to determine torque done?

answers.text: from the vector product of the interacting fields

qas.question: What is the formulia to determine torque?

answers.text: the integral of all the vectors of force multiplied by the radius of each vector

qas.question: What needs to be unknown to calculate torque?
How are the very few calculations to determine torque done?

plausible_answers.text: vector product of the interacting fields
integral of all the vectors of force multiplied by the radius of each vector

qas.question: What is the formula to not determine torque?

context: All the electromagnetic motors, and that includes the types mentioned here derive the torque <a2_0>from the <b6_0>vector product of the interacting fields<b6_0/><a2_0/>. For calculating the torque it is necessary to know the <a0_0><b4_0>fields in the air gap<b4_0/><a0_0/> . Once these have been established by mathematical analysis using <a1_0><b5_0>FEA<b5_0/><a1_0/> or other tools the torque may be calculated as <a3_0>the <b7_0>integral of all the vectors of force multiplied by the radius of each vector<b7_0/><a3_0/>. The current flowing in the winding is producing the fields and for a motor using a magnetic material the field is not linearly proportional to the current. This makes the calculation difficult but a computer can do the many calculations needed.
